history.content: For 61C, it can help to learn a bit of C beforehand since you jump into it fairly quickly, but beyond that I wouldn't spend too much of your summer worrying about fall courses. Reviewing past course notes could also be helpful, but probably the most useful thing for me when taking the course was to go through all the information in the Task Manager (on Windows, at least) and figure out what exactly it means by committed and cached memory, paged pools, processes/threads/handles, logical processers, and so on. You can figure out the basics of most of these things through a simple Google search, but piecing it all together beforehand would probably be a useful few-hour exercise that can prepare you to understand what you'll be learning in the course. (as a side note, comparing all of these specs between laptops in the airport computer store is a great way to get annoyed looks from the store clerks :) ). I haven't taken 170, but reviewing CS 70 notes and practicing programming interview questions on any common review site (I've heard GeeksForGeeks has lots of problems similar to 170, if that helps) should help.

I'll be taking these two next semester; does anyone have advice on either class in terms of what I can do over summer to be better prepared in the fall? I have the time to review past materials if that would be beneficial, but I'd like to hear what students who have taken one/both of these classes think. Thanks!
history.subject: 61C + 170
